title: Fred Robbins
text:
Fred Robbins (born March 25, 1977) is a former <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="defensive%20tackle">defensive tackle</a>. He was <a href="NFL%20Draft">drafted</a> by the <a href="Minnesota%20Vikings">Minnesota Vikings</a> in the second round of the <a href="2000%20NFL%20Draft">2000 NFL Draft</a>. He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at <a href="Wake%20Forest%20Demon%20Deacons%20football">Wake Forest</a>.
Robbins also played for the <a href="New%20York%20Giants">New York Giants</a> and <a href="St.%20Louis%20Rams">St. Louis Rams</a>.
Early years.
Robbins attended <a href="J.%20M.%20Tate%20High%20School">J. M. Tate High School</a> in <a href="Pensacola%2C%20Florida">Pensacola, Florida</a> and was a student and a letterman in <a href="high%20school%20football">football</a> and baseball. In football, he was a three-year <a href="Letterman%20%28sports%29">letterman</a> and as a senior, he was an All-City selection and an All-Northwest Florida selection.
College career.
Robbins started every game for three years at <a href="defensive%20tackle">defensive tackle</a> and finished his career with 15 quarterback sacks and 44 tackles-for-loss. He was a Second-team All-<a href="Atlantic%20Coast%20Conference">ACC</a> choice as a senior. He helped the Demon Deacons’ defense improve from 9th to 2nd in the ACC in 1999.
Professional career.
Minnesota Vikings.
Robbins was drafted on the second round of the <a href="2000%20NFL%20Draft">2000 NFL Draft</a> by the <a href="Minnesota%20Vikings">Minnesota Vikings</a>. He signed a four-year $5.5 million deal with the Vikings. As a rookie in <a href="2000%20NFL%20season">2000</a>, played in 8 games as a reserve and had 5 tackles and one sack. In <a href="2001%20NFL%20season">2001</a>, played in 16 games with 12 starts and had 45 tackles (16 solo) and 2 sacks. In <a href="2002%20NFL%20season">2002</a>, played in 16 games with 15 starts for the Vikings and recorded 41 tackles (23 solo). Robbins led the team with 7 tackles for loss and had a career-high 4 passes defensed. In <a href="2003%20NFL%20season">2003</a>, he played in all 16 games with 12 starts for the Vikings and finished with 30 tackles, 5 tackles for loss, and 5 quarterback hurries and recovered one fumble.
New York Giants.
On March 7, 2004, Robbins signed with the <a href="New%20York%20Giants">New York Giants</a> for six years and $20 million, including a $4 million bonus. In his first season with the Giants in <a href="2004%20NFL%20season">2004</a>, he started all 15 games and recorded 40 tackles (31 solo), 5 sacks, 1 interception, 2 passes defensed and 2 forced fumble. In <a href="2005%20NFL%20season">2005</a>, played in all 16 regular season games with 6 starts at <a href="defensive%20tackle">defensive tackle</a> and finished the season with 23 tackles (14 solo), 1.5 sacks, 1 pass defensed and 1 fumble recovery. In <a href="2006%20NFL%20season">2006</a>, Robbins started all 16 regular season games and the NFC Wild Card Game and finished with career-high totals of 62 tackles (39 solo), 5.5 sacks, 2 interceptions and 34 quarterback hurries. In <a href="2007%20NFL%20season">2007</a>, he played in 16 regular season with 15 starts and started all 4 postseason games and finished with 42 tackles (21 solo), 5.5 sacks, 26 QB hurries, 10 QB hits and 1 pass defensed.
Robbins was also picked by his teammates to be a defensive captain for the <a href="2008%20NFL%20season">2008 season</a>. In 2008, he started in all 14 regular season games in which he played and had 36 tackles (24 solo), 5.5 sacks and 3 passes defensed. It was the 3rd consecutive season he finished with 5.5 sacks, his career high. He was named to the 2008 "<a href="Sports%20Illustrated">Sports Illustrated</a>" All-Pro team.
Robbins had microfracture surgery following the 2008 season, and managed just two sacks in 16 games in 2009.
St. Louis Rams.
Robbins signed a three-year $11.3 million contract with the St. Louis Rams. The deal included a roster bonus of $3.4 million. He was released following the <a href="2011%20NFL%20season">2011 season</a> on March 12, 2012.
